An Aft to feeure the Colleftion of the Duties on Auftions in

Ireland; and to prevent Frauds therein. [17th March 1807.]

*	Provifions as may be necessary, should be < nafted be it therefore er.afted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Confent of the Lards Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament affembledi and by the Authority of the fame, That so much of an Aft made in the Parliament of Ireland in the Thirty-eighth Year of His present Majefty’s Reign, intituled, /;<■ Act to secure the Collection of the Duties on Auftions and on Glafs Bottles made in this Kingdom-, and onPaper printed, painted, or

II.	And for the better securing the Payment of the Duties on Auftions in Ireland, be it enacted, That no Perfon whatsoever, who at an v Time after the said Twenty-fourth Day of March One thousand eight hundred and seven, shall exercise the Trade or Bufmefs of an Auctioneer or Seller by Commiffion at any Sale of any Estate, Goods, or Effefts whatsoever, by Outery, Knccking-down of Hammer, by Candle, by Lot, by Pareel, or by any. other Mode of Sale at Auftion, or whereby the highelt Bidder is deemed to be the Pur-chafer, or who shall aftt in such Capacity, shall deal in, vend, or fell, or put up to Sale, any Estate, Goods, or Effefts whatsoever, by Public Sale, or otherwise by way of Auftion as aforesaid, in any Manner whatsoever in Ireland, without first taking out a Licence to fell by Auftion from the Commissioners of Inland Excife and Taxes io Ireland, or any One of them, or from some Perfon or Perfons appointed by the laid Commissioners, or any Three of them, for that Purpcfe, 2nd every such Licence shall be of force until the Twenty-fcfkh Day of March next after the Time of the granting thereof

XV.	And be it further enacted, That in ‘cafe any Error shall be discovered in any Charge of Duty against any Auctioneer by a greater Amount of Duty than ought to have been charged against such Auctioneer, it shall and may be lawful for him to make his Complaint within Six Calendar Months- next after the Error shall have been diicove/ed, before the said Commiflioners of Inland Excile and Taxes, who are hereby authorized and requ red to hear and determine such Complaint, an i upon Proof thereof to relieve the Party so complaining of so much of the Duty, as shall appear to have been overcharged, and if such L'uty shall have been paid it shall and may lawful for the said Commiflioners to repay the fame : And in case it shall be discovered that any Error has been committed by charging any Auctioneer with a less Amount of Duty than ought t© have been charged, it shall and may be lawful fertile Examinator of the Auction Duty, and he is hereby required to rectify the.fame as speedily as may be convenient, and to report the fame to the said Commiflioners^ of Inland Excife and Taxes, who are hereby required to give Notice to such Auctioneer of the Amount of the Deficiency of the Duty in consequence of such Error ; and if such Auctioneer shall not within one Month alter such Notice shew fufikdent Caufe to such Commiflioners of Inland Excife and Taxes why he should not be charged with and pay such Deficiency, it shall and may be lawful for the said Commiflioners to order a Return to be made by the said Examinator of the Auction Duty to the Office of the Collector of Excife in which the erroneous Charge was returned, and the Duties specified in the Return of such Examinator, shall be a Surcharge on such Auctioneer ; and if such Auctioneer shall not on Demand, or within Ten Days next after, pay the full Amount of such Duties so surcharged, such Auctioneer shall forfeit the Sum of Ten Pounds, together with a Sum equal to Double the Amount of the Duty which shall be so surcharged : Provided, that no such Return shall be a Surcharge on any Auctioneer, unless it shall have been made and the Amount demanded within Six Months after the Difcovery of the Error.

Xill And be it further enacted. That all the Clauses, Regular tions, and Provifions in this Adt contained, shall and may be applied in the levying and recovering of all Duties and Taxes, and Arrears of Duties and Taxes, imposed by any former Add or A dts in force in Ireland on or before the said Twenty-fifth Day of March One thousand eight hundred and seven, as fully and efFedtually, to all Intents and Purposes, as if such Duties and Taxes, and Arrears of Duties and Taxes, had become due and payable under this Adt.

CAP. XX.

An Adi to fuspend, until the First Day of May One thousand eight hundred and seven, the Payment of all Drawbacks on Spirits made or distilled in Great Britain or Irelandy and exported from either Country to the other respectively.

\_iyth. March 1807.]

f XTJTHEREAS by the Acts for the Union of Great Britain and t VV Ireland it is among ft other Things provided that any Articles ( of the Growth, Produce, or Manufacture of either Country which f are or may be subject to internal Duty, or to Duty on the Materials f of which they are composed, may be made subject on their Importar

*	tion into each Country respectively from the other, to such Counter-f vailing Duty as shall appear to be just and reasonable in respect of 1 such internal Duty or Duties on the Materials, and that upon the

*	Export of the said Articles from each Country to the other refpec-‘ tively, a Drawback shall be given equal in Amount to the Counter*. < vailing Duty payable on such Articles on the Import thereof into

*	the fame Country from the other : And whereas by the said Acts,

*	and by other Acts of Parliament now in force, certain Countervailing

*	Duties are chargeable on Spirits made or distilled in Great Britain on

*	the Importation thereof into Ireland, and on Spirits made or diftilled

*	in Ireland on the Importation thereof into Great Britain, and certain ‘ Drawbacks are in certain Cafes payable on the Export of such Spirits

*	from either Country to the other respectively: And whereas Doubts

*	have arisen whether certain of the said Duties and Drawbacks are 1 just and reasonable, and how far the fame are therefore confident with

*	the Letter and Spirit of the said Acts for the Union of Great Bri-c tain and Ireland: For Remedy thereof, and to'the Intent that such ‘ Countervailing Duties should be imposed, such Drawbacks allowed, f and such Provifions made as shall be judged proper for putting the

*	Trade between Great Britain and Ireland, in respect of Home-made f Spirits, upon a just, fair, and equitable Footing, according to the c true Meaning and Spirit of the said Acts for the Union of G'eat f Britain and Ireland. and also that fufticient Time may be afforded f for ascertaining just and reasonable Countervailing Duties and Draw-c backs, and for making such necefiary Provifions as aforesaid, it is ‘ expedient that the Payment of all Drawbacks upon the Export ‘ of such Spirits from each Country to the other respectively should f be suspended for a limited Time ^ be it therefore enacted by the King?s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Confent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament aflembled? and by the Authority of the fame, That, from and after the Twentieth Day of February One thousand eight hundred and seven, the Payment of all Drawbacks for or in respect of such Spirits on the Exportation thereof from any Part of Great Britain to Ireland, or from Ireland to any Part of Great Britain respectively, shall be suspended until the First Day of May One thousand eight hundred and seven,

ff Act njay be altered or repealed this Spflion. § 2f

CAP. XXXII.

An Adi for puriifhing Mutiny and Defertion; and &r the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters.

[23d March 1807.]

WHEREAS the raising or keeping a Handing Army within the I nited Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland in Time of Peace* unless it be with the Confent of Parliament, is against Law: And whereas it is judged necessary by His Majesty, and this present Parliament, that a Body of Forces iftould be continued for the Safety of the United Kingdom, the Defence of the Poflef-fiorvs of His Majefty’s Crown, and the Prefervation of the Balance of Power in Europe ; and that the whole Number of such Forces should consist of One hundred and thirteen thousand seven hundred ' and nineiy-five efiedtive Men ; And whereas during the late War in which His Majesty has been engaged, some Part of His Majefty’s Forces exceeding the Number aforesaid, has been employed in distant Parts beyond the Seas, which must render the Time when A such Forces may return Home uncertain, some of which are in-J tended to be broken, and others reduced as soon after such Arrival as conveniently may be : And whereas no Man can be forejudged of Life or Limb, or subjected in Time of Peace to any Kind of Punifh-. ment within this Realm, by Martial Law, or in any other Manner * than by the Judgement of his Peers, and according to the known 4 and established Laws of this Realm ; yet nevertheless it being re-4 quisite, for the retaining all the before mentioned Forces in their 4 Duty, that an ex ad! Diicipline be observed, and that Soldiers who 4 shall mutiny or stir up Sedition, or shall desert His Majefty’s Ser-4 vice, be brought to a more exemplary and speedy Punifhment than 4 the usual Forms of the Law will allow be it herefore enabled by the King’s mo ft Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Confent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament afiembled, and by the Authority of the fame. That if any Perfon who is or shall be commifiioned or in Pay as an .Officer# or who is or shall be lifted or in Pay as a Non-commiffioned Officer or Soldier, shall, at any Time during the Continuance of this -Acl, begin, excite, cause, or join in any Mutiny or Sedition in any Regiment, Troop or Company, either of Kis Majefty’s Land or .Marine Foroes, or shall not use his utmost Endeavours to suppress the Tame, or coming to the Knowledge .of any Mutiny, or intended Mutiny, shall not without Delay, give Information thereof to his Commanding Officer; or shall miibehave himfelfbefore the Enemy; or shall ihamefully abandon or deliver up any Garrifon, Fortress, Poft, ■or Guard committed to his Charge, or which he shall he commanded ±0 defend ; or fhal-l compel the Governor or Commanding Officer of any Garrifon, Fortress, or Poft, to deliver up to the Enemy, or to ^abandon the fame ; or shall speak Words, or use any other Means to ■induce such Governor or Commanding Officer, or others, to mifbe-•fiave before tfie Enemy, or ihamefully to abandon or deliyer up any TJarrifon, Fortress, Poft? or Guard committed to their refpe£tive • _	G	3	Charge^

V.	And be it further enacted, That from and after the said First Day of may One Thousand eight hundred and seven, all Insurances whatsoever to be effected upon or in respect to any of the tracting, dealing, carrying, removing, trans-shipping, or other Transactions by this Act prohibited, shall be also prohibited and declared to be unlawful; and if any of His Majesty's Subject's, or any Person or Persons resident within this United Kingdom, or within any of the Islands, Coionics, Dominions, or Territories thereunto belonging, or in His Majesty's Possession or Occupation, shall knowingly and willfully subscribe, efsect, or make, or cause or procure to be subscribed, effected, or made, any such unlawful Insurances or Insurance, he or they shall forfeit and pay for every such Offence the Sum of One hundred Pounds for every such Insurance, and also Treble the Amount paid or agreed to be paid as the Premium of any such Insurance, the One Moiety thereof to the Use of His Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, and the other Moiety to the Use of any Person who shall inform, sue, and prosecute for the same.

VI.	Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend, or be deemed or construed to extend, to prohibit or render unlawful the dealing or trading in the Purchase, Sale, barter, or Transfer, or the carrying away or removing for the Purpose of being sold, transferred, used, or dealt with as Slaves, or the detaining or confining for the Purpose of being so carried away or removed, of any Slaves which shall be exported, carried, or removed from Africa, in any Ship or Vessel which, on or before the said First Day of may One thousand eight hundred and seven, shall have been lawfully cleared out from Great Britain according to the Law now in force for regulating the carrying of Slaves from Africa, or to prohibit or render unlawful the manning or navigating any such Ship or Vessel, or to make void any Insurance thereon, so as the Slaves to be carried therein shall be finally landed in the West Indies on or before the First Day of March One thousand eight hundred and eight, unless prevented by Capture, the Loss of the Vessel, by the Appearance of an Enemy upon the Coast, or other unavoidable Necessity, the Proof whereof shall lie upon the Coast, or other unavoidable Necessity, the proof whereof shall lie upon the Party charged; any Thing herein-before contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

An Aft to amend and render more effectual Three Afts, made in the Eleventh, Fifteenth, and Thirty-feventh Years of His present Majesty, for the Regulation and Improvement of the Fifheries of the River Tweed.	[25th April	1807.]

HERE AS by an Aft made in the Eleventh Year of the Reign of ITis present Majesty, intituled, An Aft for regu-c kiting and improving the Fifheries in the River Tweed, and the Rivers c and Streams running into the fame, and also within the Mouth or c Entrance of the said River, certain Provifons and Regulations were c established for the Preservation,and Improvement of the said Fifh-‘ evies : And Whereas another Aft was made in the Fifteenth Year e of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Atlfor amending *■ and rendering more effectual an AB pnjfed in the Eleventh Tear of His

*	prefent Mayfly's Reigny intituled, £ An AB for regulating and improving “ the Fifheries in the River Tweed, and the Rivers and Streams running <c into the fame, and also within the Mouth or Entrance of the said River :

*	and Fifteenth Tears of the Reign of His present Majesty, for the ( Regulation and Improvement of the Fifheries in the River Tweed,

6 the Mouth or Entrance of the said River:	And	Whereas	it has

f been found by Experience that the Penalties for killing Fifh within i the Periods prohibited by the said Afts of the Eleventh and Fif-€ teenth Years of His present Majesty, have, from the increased Price ‘ of Fifh, become totally inadequate to the Purpofe intended; and 6 it is therefore expedient that the Amount of the Penalties should be c encreased : And Whereas it is expedient more effectually to deteft ‘ and prevent all unlawful Modes of ftfhing and taking Fifh in the faid

<	Rivers and Streams, to appoint Water Bailiffs, and to grant a Rate r or Affeffment upon the Rent of the said Fifheries for their Payment,

*	the Rellridtions herein-after mentioned be it therefore enacted, by the King’s moll Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Confent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the fame. That it shall and may be lawful for the Commissioners of Inland Excile and Taxes in Ireland, or any Four of them, to grant any Licence to any Perfon or Perfons in Ireland to keep and use, from and after the Twenty-ninth Day of September One thousand eight hundred and seven, any Still or Stills the Body whereof, without the Head or any other Appendage thereto, shall be capable of containing less than Five hundred Galions, and not less than Two hundred Galions, in such Place or Places in Ireland as such Commissioners or any Four of them shall think proper, any Thing in the laid recited Adi to the contrary notwithstanding : Subject nevertheless to such Reftridlions and Provilions as are herein-after mentioned and contained.

An A£t for more effectually charging Publick Accountants with Interefl upon Balances ; and for other Purpofes relating to the passing of Publick Accounts. [8th Augujl 1807.]

4 TT7HEREAS an Aft was made and palled in the Thirty-ninth and 4 VV Fortieth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, 4 An A Cl for more effectually charging Publick Accountants with the Pay-c ment of Interejl, and for allowing Inter ejl to them in certain Cases, and 4 for compelling the Payment of Balances due from them ; by which Aft 4 certain Provifions were made for charging Publick Accountants, 4 who have been concerned in the Receipt of the Revenue, with 4 Interefl upon Balances appearing to have remained in their Hands 4 at the Determination of their Service, and also for charging other 4 Publick Accountants with Interefl upon Balances remaining in their 4 Hands at the Time of the auditing of their Accounts ; And Whereas 4 it is j aft and reasonable that Perfons who have improperly and un-4 necessarily retained in their Hands large Balances of Publick Money 4 should in certain Cafes be charged with Interefl upon such Balances ; 4 but no Power is given by the said Aft to charge such Perfons with 4 Interest, except in the Cafes which are particularly specified in the 4 said AftBe it therefore enacted by the King’s mofl Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Confent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, irnthis present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the fame. That in all Cafes in which it shall appear, upon the Examination or Audit of Publick Account, that Balances of Publick Money have improperly and unnecessarily remained in the Hands of the Accountant, it shall be lawful for the Commiflioners for auditing the Publick Accounts, and all other Officers who shall be charged with the Duty of examining and finally passing such Accounts, and they are hereby authorized, in all Cafes in which it shall appear to them to be just and reasonable, to charge such Accountant with Interefl upon the Whole or any Part of the said Balances, for such Period of Time pafl, and at such Rate, not exceeding Five Pounds per Centum per Annpm, as they shall deem reasonable, although it shall appear that such Accountants were not indebted at theTime or in the Manner mentioned and specified in the said Aft of the Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty ; any Thing in the said Aft contained to the contrary notwith• {landing.

II. And be it further enacted, That in all Cafes in which it shall appear to the Commiflioners for auditing the Publick Accounts, upon the Audit of any Account which shall take place after the passing of this Aft, that the Accountant has improperly and unnecessarily retained in his Hands during a Courfe of Years, Balances pf Publick .Money, and made Interefl or Advantage thereof, it shall be lawful for the said Commissioners, at their Difcretion, upon due Confideration of the Circumflances . of the Cafe, to make annual Refts in the Account of such Accountant, in like Manner as is practised in fimiliar Cafes by Courts of Equity, and to charge the Accountant with Interefl upon the Balances appearing upon such Refts, for such Periods, and at such Rate of Interest, not exceeding Five Pounds per Centum per Annum, as they shall deem just and reasonable.

III.	And be it further enacted, That the said Commissioners and

all other publick Officers, who are or may be charged with the Duty of examining and finally palling any Publick Accounts, shall and they are hereby required, in all Cafes in which they shall charge Publick Accountants with Interect, to cause a Notice in Writing to be delivered forthwith to the accounting Party or his lawful Reprefen-tative, or to the Agent of such Party or Representative, specifying the Amount and Particulars of the Charge for Interect, and the Mode of computing the fame, together with the Grounds upon which such Charge of Intereft shall have been made ; and the said Commif-fioncrs for auditing the Publick Accounts are also hereby required in all such Cases, to fet forth the Amount and Particulars of the said Charge for Interect, together with the Mode of computing the fame, and the Grounds of such Charge upon the Face of the Account, when the said Commissioners shall cause the said Account according to the Nature thereof, either to be prepared for Declaration, or stated to the Lords Commissioners of His Majefty’s Treasury for their Confideration.	!

IV.	And be it further enacted, That in all Cafes in which the accounting Party or his Reprefentative or Reprefentatives, shall be diflatisfted with any Charge for Intereft made by the said Commissioners or other Public Officers having the Examination of his Account, it shall be lawful for him or them within Six Months from the Time of receiving the Notice herein-before directed to be given, to apply for Relief against the Whole or any Part of such Charge for Interect, by Motion in a summary way to' the Barons of His Majefty’s Court of Exchequer at Wejlmlnjler ; who shall upon such Application call before them as well the laid Commissioners or other Public Officers, or some Perfon on their Behalf, as the accounting Party, and shall cause Notice thereof to be sent to His Majefty’s Attorney General ; and after hearing what shall be alledged by the different Parties, shall make such Order thereupon as the Juftice of the Cafe shall require ; and the several Officers and Perfons whose Duty it shall be to make up the said Accounts, shall govern themselves accordingly.

V.	And be it further enacted, That all Charges of Interect, which shall be made by virtue of the present Adi, shall have the fame force and effect as if the fame had been made under the Authority of the aforesaid Adi of the rThirty-ninth and Fortieth Year oft the Reign of His present Majesty, and shall be subject to the fame Approbation and Controul of the Lords Commissioners of His Majefty’s Treasury ; and the Commissioners for auditing the Public Accounts, and all other proper Officers, shall observe the fame Courfe of Proceeding, with respect to all Charges of Intereft to be made under the Authority of the present Adi, as if such Charges had been made under the Authority of the said Adi of the Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Year of His present Majesty, except so far as such Courfe of Proceeding is in any Manner affected or varied by the present Adi.

VI.	And be it further enacted, That any Account which shall hereafter be delivered into the Office for auditing the Publick Accounts, may be attested before any One of the Commissioners for auditing the said Accounts.

And be it further enacted, That whenever any Magiftrate or other Perfon fha.Il seize or carry away any Arms or Weapons as aforesaid, such Magiftrate or other Perfon shall with all convenient Difpatch transmit the fame to One of His Majefty’s Storehouses, or to the Officer commanding the nearest Detachment of His Majefty’s Troops, by him to be transmitted as aforesaid ; and that in every Cafe such Magiftrate or other Perfon as aforesaid shall, immediately after he or they shall have seized or carried away any Arms or Weapons as aforesaid, transmit to the Lord Lieutenant or other Chief Governor or Governors of Ireland, or to his or their Chief Secretary, a written Account of the Number and Nature of such Arms‘or Weapons, and of the Place where, and the Perfon from whom such Arms or Weapons were respectively seized.

XIV.	And be it further enacted, That all the Pecuniary Penalties in this Acl specified shall be raised and levied by Sale of the Goods of the Perfon offending, by Warrant under‘the Hand and Seal of any Juftice of the Peace in and for the County in which such Offence shall be committed; and the Penalties so to be levied shall be by such Justices or Juftice handed over to the Treasurer of the County in which such Sums are levied, to be applied to such Purposes as the Grand Jury at any ensuing Affixes shall think proper to present.

XV.	And be it further enacted, That whenever any Search shall be made under this Add, by any Perfon authorized by any Warrant of any Juftice of Peace under the Authority of this Adi, the Justices of Peace authorizing and diredling any Perfon or Perfons to make such Search, shall make a true and faithful Return of the Name arid Names of all and every Perfon or Perfons io authcffzed to make such Search and their Quality and Defcriptions, to the General Seffion of the Peace which shall be held next after such Search.

XVI.	And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the Grand Jury of every County, County of a City, and County of a Town in Ireland, at each Afsizes, and for the Grand Jury at each Prefenting Term for the County and County of the City of Dublin, and they are hereby respectively required, to present such Sum to be raised off the County as may be requisite to reward the Clerks of the Peace respectively for their Trouble in the Execution of this Adi, not exceeding the Sum of Ten Pounds at any one such Affizes or Prefenting Term.

XVII.	And be it further enacted, That this Adi shall continue in force from the palling thereof for Two Years, and from thence until the End of the then next Seffion of Parliament.

4 TT7HEREAS there is a certain Trad of Sands situate on the 4 VV Elluary called Traeth-Mawr, dividing the Counties of Car-4 narvon and Merioneth, and extending from Pont Alerglajlyn to the 4 Point of Gefi, which in its present State,, is unproductive and inca-4 pable of being cultivated, and the Palfage over the fame is frequently 4 attended with great Inconvenience, Delay, -Difficulty, Expence, 4 and Danger: And Whereas, if the said Sands were protected from 4 the Sea by Embankments and other necessary Works, the fame might 4 be cultivated and rendered productive, and the Communication * between the said Two Counties would be thereby greatly facilitated 4 and improved, and such Embankments and Works would also be 4 of publick Utility; but the making and maintaining of the fame £ will be attended with confiderable Difficulty and Expence : And 4 Whereas William Alexander Mado ks, of Tan yr A lit, in the County -4 of Carnarvon, Esquire, is desirous of conftruding and making 4 such Embankments, Sea Walls, Ramparts, Fences, Sluices, 4 Bridges, and other Works, as may be necessary for protecting the 4 said Sands from the Influx of the Sea, at his own Expence, on 4 having the fame veiled in him and his Heirs and Affigns in Fee 4 Simple: And Whereas His Majesty, in right of His Crown, 4 claims to be entitled to the said Sands, and being desirous of 4 encouraging Undertakings of publick Utility, His Majesty has been c moll graciously pleased to lignify his Royal Pleasure, that so much 4 of the said Trad of Sands from the Point of Ged to Pont Abcrglajlyn 4 afore said, as shall be protected from the Influx of the Sea, by the laid 4 Wi liam Alexander Madocks, his Heirs or Afsigns, in Manner afore-4 said, shall (as far as His Majesty is interested therein) be granted 4 and confirmed to, and veiled in the said William Alexander Madocks, 4 his Heirs and Afsigns, in Fee Simple:

LXII. ‘ And Whereas it would tend greatly to the Prevention of < Fraud, if certain particular Quantities of Coals only were permitted e to be loaded info Barges, Ligliters, or other Craft, from Ships and 6 other Veflels discharging their Cargoes of Coals in the said River ‘ Thames/ be it therefore further enacted, That if any Meter delivering Coals shall load, or permit or suffer to be loacted, from any such Ship or otherVefiel in the River Thames, into any Ligliter, Barge or other Craft, a less Quantity than Five Chaldrons and One Vat or Twenty-one Vats, or any Quantity between Five Chaldrons and One Vat or Twenty-one Vats, and Ten Chaldrons and Two Vats, or Forty-two Vats or any .Quantity between Ten Chaldrons and Two Vats or Forty-two Vats, and Fifteen Chaldrons and Three Vats or Sixty-three Vats, or any Quantity between Fifteen Chaldrons and Three Vats or Sixty-three Vats, and between Twenty-one Chaldrons or Eighty-four Vats, or otherwise so that there shall be a less Quantity than Five Chaldrons and One Vat or Twenty-one Vats, or than some Multiple ofjFive Chaldrons, and One Vat or Twenty-one Vats, in any such Ligliter, Barge, or other Craft, or in any Room or Rooms, Divifion or Divifions thereof, save and except for the Clearance of such Ship or other Veflel when the Cargo is reduced to a less Quantity than Five Chaldrons and One Vat or Twenty-one Vats, or if any Lighterman or other Perfon having the Care or Management of such Ligliter, Barge, or other Craft, shall, without the Permiflion or Confent of such Meter, take away his or their Ligliter, Barge, or other Craft from any such Ship or other Veflel, so as to prevent the fame from being loaded with the Quantity herein directed, then and in . every such Cafe every such Meter so offending, and every such Lighterman or other Perfon so offending, shall, for every such Offence, forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Twenty Pounds.
